Tuition at Hopkins is going
up next fall. The actual amount
of the increase will be decided at
a meeting of the Board of
Trustees October 8. The proposal currently before the Board
would establish an increase of 11
to 13 per cent, or $500 to S600.
That proposal has been put
forward by a Management
Committee composed of University President Steven Muller,
Provost Richard Longaker, and
Vice-Presidents Robert Bowie,
Richard Zdanis and C. Norman
Krueger.
Each year the process for
setting the following year's tuition begins with the Management Committee, which solicits
opinions from all the Deans of
every Hopkins facility. Advice is
also requested .from faculty at
large and from the Faculty
Budget Advisory Committee
which consists of two faculty
members from all Hopkins divisions -- Atts and Sciences and
Engineering, Evening College,
Hygiene and Public Health,
Medicine, and the School of
Advanced International Studies.
The two members representing
Homewood are Dr. Bela Balassa
and Dr. Wilson Rugh.
The Management Committee settles on a final recommendatio,1 to take before the
Budget Committee of the Board
of Trustees. The Board received
this year's report last Tuesday.
The Budget Committee will
present its recommendation to
the full Board on October 8. In

the past, the Budget Committee
has usually accepted the Management Committee's surggestions while the full Board has
commonly followed the Budget
Committee's ideas.
Vice-President for Management and Finance Robert Bowie
commented that the tuition
increase is cause4 by the general
rise in the Consumer Price
Index, adding that "Hopkins is
more adversly affected by inflation than the general public!'
He explained that products
Hopkins uses most, such as fuel,
are among those which have
risen most in cost. Prices for
items used less by institutions,

such as food, have not risen at a
comparable rate. Bowie also
said that "decisions on tuition
are not made on strictly budgetary terms."
Traditionally there had been
one tuition rate for all of Hopkins, but recently. each division
has been permitted to set its
own independent rate. Only the
Medical School has acted on this
privilege, establishing a higher
rate for M.D. candidates.
Bowie also noted that the
tuition at Homewood was presently half that of other northeastern schools, so that even
with the incrLse he believes

Student Mugged
At South Gate
BY CHAS HALLER
Last Saturday at approximately midnight two Hopkins
students were assaulted by a
group of about ten juveniles on
the 5, uthern part of the campus.
Or student was taken to the
hospital with a head injury and
released that night.
The students, both freshmen, were on their way back
from a party at Sig Fp. As they
approached the intersection of
Art Museum Drive and Wyman
Park Drive, they passed the
group. According to the students, the juveniles began to
follow and then to verbally
abuse them.

and onto University property.
One student, Mark Briner, reported that he was thrown to
the ground, kicked and pushed
into the ravine between the
campus and the museum. The
other student - tried to help
Briner and was struck in the
mouth and robbed of eight
dollars. Then a third student
also came to their aid and the
juveniles moved off down the
path.
The incident was reported
to Campus Security and the City
Police. So far, attempts to
locate the juveniles have failed.
According to Security, the area
where the incident took place
is routinely patrolled.

Tuition at Hopkins is going
up next fall. The actual amount
of the increase will be decided at
a meeting of the Board of
Trustees October 8. The proposal currently before the Board
would establish an increase of 11
to 13 per cent, or $500 to S600.
That proposal has been put
forward by a Management
Committee composed of University President Steven Muller,
Provost Richard Longaker, and
Vice-Presidents Robert Bowie,
Richard Zdanis and C. Norman
Krueger.
Each year the process for
setting the following year's tuition begins with the Management Committee, which solicits
opinions from all the Deans of
every Hopkins facility. Advice is
also requested .from faculty at
large and from the Faculty
Budget Advisory Committee
which consists of two faculty
members from all Hopkins divisions -- Atts and Sciences and
Engineering, Evening College,
Hygiene and Public Health,
Medicine, and the School of
Advanced International Studies.
The two members representing
Homewood are Dr. Bela Balassa
and Dr. Wilson Rugh.
The Management Committee settles on a final recommendatio,1 to take before the
Budget Committee of the Board
of Trustees. The Board received
this year's report last Tuesday.
The Budget Committee will
present its recommendation to
the full Board on October 8. In

the past, the Budget Committee
has usually accepted the Management Committee's surggestions while the full Board has
commonly followed the Budget
Committee's ideas.
Vice-President for Management and Finance Robert Bowie
commented that the tuition
increase is cause4 by the general
rise in the Consumer Price
Index, adding that "Hopkins is
more adversly affected by inflation than the general public!'

Hopkins uses most, such as fuel,
are among those which have
risen most in cost. Prices for
items used less by institutions,

such as food, have not risen at a
comparable rate. Bowie also
said that "decisions on tuition
